Posts.Title: Concerned about upcoming biopsy

Posts.Content: Yes, I've had a similar sensation......along with a multitude of other odd pains (that the docs could only guess about and assure me things would get better) and weird feelings in the plumbing. My surgery was February 4th and the time since has been an interesting time period. First three weeks were nightmarish. I didn't get much sleep at all and pretty much wished I were dead. Catheter stayed in 15 days and I survived, slowly started to get more and better sleep and things have gotten progressively and slowly better. The pain you mention has gone away along with all the others......I just feel little shadows of former pains these days. After a little more than four months--I actually feel pretty good and had a 99.9% dry day yesterday while being quite active. In my experience, you can expect almost anything in the way of pain. A lot happened down there. Most of us get better, it just takes longer than we would like.
Posts.Signature: I will resume more active participation when the bellicose forum culture improves.
Posts.Title: Bladder Spasm?

Posts.Content: All I can say is.......YMMV (Your Mileage May Vary). They say women wouldn't have second children if they could remember the pain of childbirth. The fleeting memories of pain fade quickly in our relief at getting better. These words jumped out at me. I would say the key is to have a good attachment of the tube to your upper leg. That holds the tube in a comfortable position. I got ZERO instruction on this crucial issue. They gave me a ridiculous DVD with general info and an equally useless written pamphlet with zero info on details like the above. They just showed me how to attach everything and sent me on my way without covering details like the above. Worse.....they initially hooked it up with very little slack so any movement was tugging at the penis and was painful (and, I'm sure, causing my bladder spasms). When I asked--the nurse said the doctor likes the caths snug at first and that he would probably adjust it when he stopped by later. Never happened and I stupidly just copied the way things were adjusted for the next few days.......and had a lot of pain. I called and they said take the anti-spasm med. Well, that was stupid. Didn't deal with the problem at all. When I went in a week later with bloody urine the urology folks showed me how things should REALLY be hooked up--and sentenced me to seven more days with the cath. Urine is clearing now, but very slowly. Just taking my hourly walk around the house brings on a slightly darker pink for a while. I just hope no serious damage was done. So.......for some of us at least, the cath can be a painful trial. There's a lot of luck involved in this complicated surgery. It has many aspects and slight details can make a big difference. Nurses are obviously busy, understaffed and under a lot of pressure to move patients out quickly.....and things get lost in a process like that. Unacceptable.

Posts.Title: Catheter-How bad/uncomfortable is it? Or it's NOT that bad?

Posts.Content: Sleeping at night is not a major issue either.Just ensure there are no kinks in the line and the big bag is well below you for proper flow. I had mine in for 2 weeks and still enjoyed going out for lunch, movies, etc. Sleeping is an issue if you would not normally sleep on your back. And it's a BIG issue if you really never sleep on your back. Tossing and turning, moving legs, etc., will tend to cause pain of various kinds. As for going out.....that's a laugh. I have never once felt like going anywhere except on my hourly walk around the house.

Posts.Title: What caused decrease in psa ?

Posts.Content: The biopsy is a pain in the ass (well, mostly the prostate itself) in more ways than one, quite bearable, but not something you want to do if you don't have to do it. It also has some risk of dangerous infections that can be troublesome in older men (I'm 67). And......I still have a small amount of discomfort at times and a small amount of dark brown blood in the urine at bowel movements after 14 days. I'm hoping there are no real problems lingering, like a low-grade infection of some kind. Then there's the question of when I go back on aspirin again and the question as to whether going off the aspirin a day regimen puts me at any increased risk for heart attack or stroke (nobody knows for sure, of course). If.....IF your PSA and digital exam are not totally damning, you CAN, as I did, ask for a PCA-3 and the MRI with rectal coil first. The MRI is annoying, but not painful and no risks involved and the information was useful in more ways than one. If mine had been clear I'd have opted for taking a few months before trying more testing. My PCA-3 was negative, but MRI showed "concerning" results that meant likely cancer in the prostate, so I then agreed to the biopsy (which turned up two 4/3 samples with the rest clear). In my case I may have just wasted time, but it gave me peace of mind and really only wasted about 10 days. I am lucky enough to be near a world-class facility, and would advise anybody starting this journey to get to the best place that's within reasonable reach in order to minimize risk and maximize good results. Remember that prostate cancer is unique to every man and comparing yourself to others is fairly unproductive. Your experience may well be totally different from any you read about here, so just do your homework and make decisions that feel right to you.

Posts.Content: It's very easy to be a little TOO cynical in these situations. I think it's usually more driven by .... 1. Tradition 2. Habit 3. Set protocols Profit is in there somewhere and will probably vary by institution. Change comes slowly to the medical profession.....they are not risk-takers and any deviation from the established ways is risk.
Posts.Title: MRI prior to biopsy?

Posts.Content: It's very easy to be a little TOO cynical in these situations. I think it's usually more driven by .... 1. Tradition 2. Habit 3. Set protocols Profit is in there somewhere and will probably vary by institution. Change comes slowly to the medical profession.....they are not risk-takers and any deviation from the established ways is risk.
Posts.Title: MRI prior to biopsy?

Posts.Content: You must know and define your goals. The MRI with rectal coil cannot diagnose cancer for sure, but it can tell you that you "for sure" need a biopsy. Conversely, it can also tell you that it is HIGHLY unlikely that cancer exists. Thus saving you from the needless risk posed by the biopsy. That is my understanding of the situation as explained by my doctors during my recent experience. A biopsy has dangers and multiple biopsies may do cumulative damage to the prostate that does actual harm to the prostate that's getting stabbed.
Posts.Title: MRI prior to biopsy?

Posts.Content: In some cases the push for biopsies may simply be because biopsies are QUICK and PROFITABLE and MRIs are slow and not so profitable. Also, doctors have a set protocol and they're pretty much stuck with it. It's difficult to jar them out of that protocol. I did it by simply talking to the doctor until he gave up. When I finally mentioned that I had read of three doctors in my circumstances who had MRIs prior to the biopsy and I didn't see why I shouldn't get the same consideration.......he scheduled me for a PCA3 test and an MRI with rectal coil. Yes, biopsies are somewhat painful, but more importantly, there ARE real risks, especially for older men. Infections sometimes put people in the hospital and those cases have been INCREASING due to resistant bacteria. I'm 67 and I took the risks quite seriously. MRI was not painful and there was no risk of infection. In my case the MRI showed that cancer was likely, so the next step was the biopsy anyway. But, if the MRI had been clear I'd have avoided the danger of the biopsy and gone happily on my way with more tests scheduled in a few months. As to your PSA.......my first doctor (who I quickly discarded) sent me for the PSA immediately after the digital rectal exam. That one came back 4.8 and a subsequent PSA (correctly done) came back 2.8......so there IS a big difference when you do it correctly. I'd say everyone who has any doubts at all should simply insist on the MRI with rectal coil BEFORE the biopsy.

Posts.Content: Well, you certainly want to delay surgery as long as possible, because while you may be CLOSE to the same afterwards, you'll never be exactly the same and with just a little bad luck may never regain certain functions. That said, you are certainly approaching the limits. I'd have to say that you need to go ahead sooner rather than much later and err on the side of being able to get cancer-free. It would be nice if we could get more precise information to make decisions, but nobody knows for sure what to do in any particular case......they are all pretty much unique.

Posts.Title: Decisions, decisions. Surgery or remain on AS with Gleason 3+4

Posts.Content: Third opinion couldn't hurt (unless he recommends another biopsy--that will hurt). (A little dark humor there.) However, your world-renowned urologist didn't get that reputation by giving bad advice. My intuition tells me he figures you are in such early stages that he feels you can safely go slow. Believe me, while getting surgery too LATE is a big problem.......the MOST damage these days is done by treatment that comes too often and too early--and your rock-star urologist knows that. A lot of the Mayo doctors don't even do routine PSA screening anymore because it is unreliable and it ends up doing more harm than good. Repeated biopsies are not good for you......and that's only the beginning of what's not good for you--the stress and even anguish can be crushing. I remember doctors saying that the left side of my prostate felt a little odd when I was in my 40s.....here I am finally getting my first biopsy and surgery at age 67. Thank God they didn't start messing with me when I was 50.......because some of the happiest and best years of my life would have been ruined for nothing. Maybe your doctor is just protecting you from that.
Posts.Signature: I will resume more active participation when the bellicose forum culture improves.
Posts.Title: New Member w/Rising PSA

Posts.Content: Yes, and I suppose as a Medicare patient they will give me the speed-dating version of a physical from now on because Medicare does not reimburse them enough to make huge profits for them. I may have had one chest x-ray in the last 15 years in the Mayo system......I'm not sure I've had even one, and I wasn't on Medicare for most of that time period. (Note: Mayo is a non-profit, but they still need as much money as they can get in order to keep offering the latest technology--which is incredibly expensive.) Thus come many cost-cutting measures. The Mayo CEO says Medicare patients must be handled with much greater efficiency than other patients. And......he says, the patient must NEVER perceive that they are getting that "more efficient" treatment. Right. LOL! Truth is, when they can't make a profit off you they're gonna find ways to deal with that problem......and you probably won't be thrilled about the kind of care you get. It's pretty much fast assembly line treatment in many situations. Wham, bam and thank you ma'am. Anyhow, I've been in the Mayo system for close to 20 years and hadn't had a PSA for six or seven years at the time my GP decided my prostate should be poked by a urologist. My doc was obviously against routine yearly PSA testing. Didn't make much difference. My PSA never got terribly high anyway......it was feeling that node on the prostate that was the real telling clue. Let's face it.....the medical profession has always involved a lot of guesswork, intuition and it's an endeavor fraught with peril and prone to mistakes. Speed it up and it ain't gonna get better. I'd wager that ALL medical facilities are running into the same problems as senior citizens begin to make up a high percentage of patients. Things get a bit chancy from here on out for all of us except the very wealthy, I think.

Posts.Title: Brand New

Posts.Content: Here's the problem. Erring on the side of safety is also erring on the side of PROFIT. Biopsies are quicker and more profitable than MRIs. They are also standard practice while an MRI is sort of a departure from standard practice. This makes it tough to get the MRI.......but why choose a painful, invasive procedure like a biopsy (with a risk of serious infection) when better, non-painful, non-dangerous methods exist? It's a choice of 21st Century medicine over 20th Century medicine. Some doctors consider the PROSTATE biopsy a barbaric procedure. I agree. Stabbing a bunch of needles through a dirty colon and thence into the innocent prostate is a process that is soon destined to be history. The time to get a biopsy is when an MRI shows an anomaly that justifies risking the biopsy. If your doc wants you to have a biopsy you usually have to go eyeball to eyeball with him to get an MRI instead of a biopsy. I know because I did it. I could tell he was a bit angry, but I had a strategy that worked. I was firm and just kept quietly asking for the MRI and he kept looking at his watch and saying the proper procedure would be a biopsy and I kept quietly asking for the MRI and......I guess he finally decided he couldn't spend any more time on me and agreed to my request. My MRI showed that I had cancer and even correctly predicted it as intermediate to high grade.....so, if you get the state-of-the-art version with rectal coil and dye injection you can get some amazing results. Biopsies are not without some risk (not huge, but real) and I refuse to EVER take ANY medical risk unless there is no other way......and I don't give a damn about the profits--I come before the profits. I was pleased with the way things went for me and I would never do it any other way.

Posts.Content: Such great urination. Do you sleep through the night, too? You don't sound like a guy with prostate cancer. The PSA is not alarming at all at your age. If the blood was taken right after a DRE the true PSA would probably be under 4. Mine went from 4.8 to 2.8 when taken properly a week after a DRE. On the other hand......I turned out to have a serious prostate cancer with that 2.8 PSA. Go figure. Then again, most guys your (our) age probably have at least a very early stage of prostate cancer (that may never need treatment). We're all guessing here, even the doctors. If you're getting a state of the art MRI with rectal coil it should reveal something if there's a serious problem.

Posts.Content: Yes, everyone must figure it out for themselves......for their own physical make-up. One 68-year-old may be very different from another 68-year-old.......same with 20s, 30s, 40s, etc. The ED/Biking equation, however, may be more universal. The pressure on nerves and blood vessels in the perineum area is probably quite tough on most men, and that cause of ED is sometimes forgotten or not even heard about for many men.

Posts.Title: Exercise/Incontinence/ED Connections

Posts.Content: I hear a lot on this forum about running, walking and bicycle riding for exercise. I also hear a lot about incontinence and ED. What I don't hear is discussion of how these four things can be connected.......meaning that running (even excessive walking) can have a detrimental effect on continence and that bicycling can cause ED. Going to a recumbent bike can solve both these problems in some (perhaps many) cases. Awareness of this fact could help a lot of people. I know well that there can be an addiction to certain specific types of exercise because they become part of a man's chosen identity.....but we have to face up to such things and make adjustments. Exercise is essential. Smart exercise and moderation are just as essential.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DTrom I'm sick of being listless, tired, forgetful, taking meds to counter act meds and basically feeling like I'm already dead. My stats are in my signature so I don't want to retype it. Has anyone else had experience in stopping HT and would you share the results? I'm due for my next injection in January and intend to see what the PSA is and then make my decision. My first thought is that you may FEEL like you're already dead in terms of energy, but you're far from dead. You're here, you're interacting with others in other places and ways and your mind is working, even if hampered by the meds. You have things that you WANT to do.......and hopes of doing those things in the future are realistic. You have a lot going on. That's WAY different from dead. Since I'm new at this, I offer mostly intuition rather than wisdom.....but, you sound like you badly need a break from the shots to recover a little from side effects. Why not try it or at least look into the possibility? Get several medical opinions. I also think a lot of people here are trying to go it alone without counseling from the psych side of things. A good psychologist can sometimes make a world of difference and more of us should probably take advantage of that. I haven't yet, but then I'm still in shock and, to a certain extent, haven't even truly accepted the fact that I have cancer. It hasn't hit me real hard yet, it seems. Anyhow......that's my two cents worth of intuition. Cheers for sure.
Posts.Title: Thinking about quitting HT. Has anyone else?

Posts.Content: It's almost a coin-flip decision for most. What tipped the balance for me was that surgery had the potential to get rid of both cancer and BPH problems. My prostate was about the same size as yours and I had minor BPH problems. I was thinking that radiation/hormones could get rid of cancer but leave me with increasing BPH problems. I don't know if that happens often or even happens at all, but I went with my intuition at that point. I felt that surgery was the harder but better choice. I have no idea if I was correct.

Posts.Content: Thanks to all for the kind comments. I also sent a message to Mayo through my page on their website and (this could not be applied to all cases, of course) got a response saying it's perfectly reasonable to limit evening fluids to minimize urine output overnight.....and the rest of the time drink to thirst and do your best to stay hydrated. Since I was a runner for many years I sort of automatically watch my urine color to stay hydrated, so I'm happy with that response. Posts.Content: Originally Posted by NYC GMAN While you need to drink a lot during the day (my doc had a daily total oz goal for the day during the first few weeks), you should stop in the evening unless you want to get up during the night. I would stop drinking by 7pm. My goal was to go through the night without getting up. Get Depends, male diapers and put a pad in it. It should keep you from wetting the bed. You can sleep on a towel for extra protection. You'll see progress over time, especially if you keep a daily chart. Keep track of when you get up during the night, pad usage, etc. Before you know it you will be charting erections, penetration, and your spouse/partners orgasms. Thanks, much, NYC.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by gearloose when i sit for a short time and goto stand up I get this searing hot pain the shoots down my leg into my knee and lower leg some times its so bad I loose my balance,and almost fall to the floor. The other problem I'm experiencing is this nasty itching and burning on my Perineum Please forgive spelling. And my scrotum feels likes a peace of raw meat. Lotion helps to calm it down but it is relentless. Thanks for your time You need a consult with a back specialist.....may just be sciatica-- "A set of symptoms including pain caused by general compression or irritation of one of five spinal nerve roots of each sciatic nerve—or by compression or irritation of the left or right or both sciatic nerves. Symptoms include lower back pain, buttock pain, and pain, numbness or weakness in various parts of the leg and foot. Other symptoms include a "pins and needles" sensation, or tingling and difficulty moving or controlling the leg. Typically, symptoms only manifest on one side of the body. The pain may radiate below the knee, but does not always. Sciatica is a relatively common form of low back and leg pain, but the true meaning of the term is often misunderstood. Sciatica is a set of symptoms rather than a diagnosis for what is irritating the root of the nerve to cause the pain. Treatment for sciatica or sciatic symptoms often differs, depending on underlying causes and pain levels. Causes include compression of the sciatic nerve roots by a herniated (torn) or protruding disc in the lower back." You need a prescription from a good dermatologist for your jock itch. This could be: http://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/e...cle/000872.htm Lichen simplex chronicus is a skin condition caused by chronic itching and scratching. Causes This disorder may occur in people who have: Skin allergies Eczema (atopic dermatitis) Psoriasis Nervousness, anxiety, depression, and other emotional problems The problem is common in children, who cannot stop scratching insect bites and other itchy skin conditions. It is also found in children who have chronic repetitive movements. Symptoms This skin disorder leads to scratching which in turn causes more itching. It may start when something that rubs, irritates, or scratches the skin, such as clothing. The person begins to rub or scratch the itchy area. Constant scratching causes the skin to thicken. The thickened skin itches, causing more scratching, which causes more thickening. The skin may become leathery and brownish in the problem area.
Posts.Title: Hip and leg pain could it be from Radation. Treatment

Posts.Content: There are many, many things to consider in most cases. Even mine, which seemed pretty simple--was not. I chose against radiation mostly because they said it had to include hormone therapy, and I didn't like the widely reported negative impacts on cognitive function. I already forget more things than I like......didn't need an increase in memory problems. Really! Also, with the horrible winter weather we've had......I COULD NOT have kept up the driving back and forth demanded by a radiation schedule and even the attempt would have been extremely stressful. Surgery won mainly by default. The previously mentioned elimination of the prostate and thus the probable elimination of most or all of the BPH issue was another important consideration. It's an incredibly personal and complex decision even when AS is not in the picture.

Posts.Content: Sugar is a known problem and a factor in many health issues. If you minimize other sugar in your diet, the sugar in a nightly small glass of red wine should not be a problem--and might save you from a heart attack or stroke that would kill you a lot quicker than prostate cancer. State of the art MRI that includes use of a rectal coil is indicated.

Posts.Title: Micro Metastatic Prostate Cancer/My Father

Posts.Content: Even if you just served one day in Vietnam you're eligible for disability for prostate cancer........and it's not just Vietnam. There's a growing number of places where the vet qualifies for service-related disability because Agent Orange was used worldwide on base perimeters, pipelines, powerlines, antenna fields, etc. Nobody knows just how widely it was used because the government is trying to minimize the disability costs and has a policy of denying the use of Agent Orange in a specific location for as long as they can before admitting it. If you think you may have been affected by this or other herbicides, you should file a claim. They played fast and loose with your health in an irresponsible way.
Posts.Title: Delay

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by glr3 I have read about the endo-rectal MRI, and it appears to have a much better result in actually determining if cancer is present in the prostate - or even if it has migrated out of the prostate as well. Why is this procedure not used first to determine if there is cancer since it is more effective in actually determining its presence, and the results could be used for biopsy purposes for grading of the cancer? Is it purely a money thing? The danger of public forums is that one can be influenced by people stating opinions not backed by experience. Be careful of that hazard. I am one who actually had an MRI with endo-rectal coil and dye injected into bloodstream so I speak from experience. The MRI detected my prostate cancer and I then felt comfortable with risking the biopsy to get more detailed information. I insisted on having the MRI PRIOR to the biopsy because the biopsy DOES have significant risk factors. Doctors generally minimize the risk factors, but the risk of the major factor--sepsis--has been increasing in recent years due to more forms of bacteria becoming resistant to antibiotics. Sepsis will put you in the hospital and in rare cases it can kill. Your age and general health level must be considered in figuring your own risk level. Is it all about money? Well.......yes, the biopsy does look like the quick and profitable alternative--taking only about 20 minutes. The MRI takes 45 minutes with at least a half hour of prep prior to that. So, biopsy is more high-volume and thus probably considerably more profitable. I am guessing, but they can probably perform three biopsies in the time spent on an MRI. More important is that the biopsy is traditional--and doctors are big on tradition......locked into it in some cases. As to your question about the PSA test, my answer (again, from actual experience) is that my PSA test was (just like yours) done incorrectly the first time (right after DRE came back with a 4.8 result) and when correctly done came back with 2.8 instead. Significant difference. Deal with the very best doctors with the latest, state of the art equipment you can find and you will have the best chance of the best outcome. Good luck.
Posts.Signature: I will resume more active participation when the bellicose forum culture improves.
Posts.Title: Alternatives to Biopsy for Determining PC ?

Posts.Content: That sucks. Sorry you ran into it. However, whether labeled "aggressive" or not, it's prostate cancer and that's not a fast-moving cancer. It's normal to worry, but try not to dwell on it now because there's nothing you can do to make things happen faster. In the meantime, get the Walsh book if you don't have it. If you want it quick, just go to the Amazon site, hook into their Kindle book sales and you can have it right here on your computer in 30 seconds. Look into making a claim for service-related disability from the VA if you haven't already. Stay strong.

Posts.Content: I can relate. I just got through my two weeks of hell--almost entirely related to the catheter. Call your doctor and get up and move around while you have him on the phone so he can hear you grunt when the pain hits you. He may have some tips about catheter use if he knows exactly what you're doing when the pain hits you. I had to keep my cath in an extra week and that extra week seemed like a year. I wasn't recovering, I was going backwards due to pain and lack of sleep. Use the bladder spasm meds if you can--I couldn't because they made my heart beat erratically. Hang in there, I'm on day 18 and feel like I'm starting my recovery.

Posts.Content: I think his expectations are unrealistic and way too high, but his positive thinking is admirable. I'm retired, so I've had time for a leisurely recovery (I'm at about nine weeks post-surgery). I feel sorry for those who were forced to go back to work quickly. I'm seven years older than him, so maybe that's a factor. As for pads, Mayo recommended and gave me a few of the Pampers 3 small diapers when I got the cath out. They said they've found these to be the best. The #3 is the perfect size for an adult to use as a pad and it's shaped so there's a little pouch that gives the equipment a little more room. Very comfortable and incredibly absorbent. Expensive, but worth it. Once you get past the Sesame Street characters that decorate the outside........ Actually, I found the Sesame Street decor to be comic relief.....he may not be able to get past it, but Mayo is right.....these are great. Best of luck......try to start lowering his expectations just in case. Catheter is a trial. I had a difficult time with mine--most seem to do better. Be prepared for some grumpiness......(I had to keep the catheter in for 15 days, it was painful and I was EXTREMELY grumpy for over a month). It gets better. I'm practically sane again now.

Posts.Title: Post Biopsy Symptoms

Posts.Content: Relax. I'm four months out and not dry yet, but making steady progress. Drinking enough water is good, but drinking too much, I suspect, can make things more difficult. Just drink enough. Drink to thirst and ease off in the evening. Watch your urine for signs of dehydration. If it gets dark yellow or orange you're not drinking enough, but if it's constantly clear and seems a little too abundant you can drink less. Kegals.......same thing. Doing enough is good. Too many can make things worse. Remember, you're using that sphincter muscle whenever you're moving around and thinking about staying dry. It gets tired. Mayo recommends six kegals before bed and maybe add another six at some point during the day if you really want to after a couple of months. Overusing that sphincter muscle will do harm. Be patient and don't be worried by all these big stories of immediate continence after catheter removal. Everybody goes at their own rate and your chances of being dry in six to nine months are very good. Just give your body time. Get plenty of rest and take naps and eat healthy and get a sufficient amount of exercise, but don't overdo exercise either. You've been through a real tough surgical procedure. Take good care of yourself.

Posts.Title: Danger of a Biopsy; allowing bad cells to spread and grow elsewhere....

Posts.Content: In conclusion, seeding along the needle track is rare complication after prostate biopsy. Its actual incidence is presently difficult to quantify. It is reasonable to advise appropriate counselling and take measures to reduce this event where possible; however, we do not advocate avoidance of biopsies as the benefits of appropriate cancer diagnosis and management outweigh any potential risks from seeding. That's basically what I said above. It's just another reason to only have a biopsy when ABSOLUTELY necessary (and there are already several reasons to avoid them). Biopsies are big business and very profitable. Don't let some doctor intimidate you into getting one. Research it yourself and get second and third opinions if there is ANY doubt at all. There are alternatives in some and perhaps many cases......and the technology for alternatives is getting better all the time. Sometimes it comes down to the reality that a biopsy is your only choice......but don't have it until that time.

Posts.Content: With mine.......I did call the doctor......several times. They said it must be bladder spasms. I was repeatedly told to take the nasty pain-killers they had given me when I left the hospital. I repeatedly told them that those pain-killers caused an erratic heartbeat so I couldn't use them. They said it was my choice and I could use them or not, it was totally up to me. They also said I could fall back on the Tylenol, but that didn't do much, if it did anything, and the suggested doses were very high so I didn't want to keep using it anyway. My only alternative was to head back in to see the doctor and I figured that the way things were going--that would probably end with more delay, more insult, more injury, more painful and annoying treatment and more damage to me in the long run anyway. Anyhow......like you, I survived. I think there was some defect with that catheter and it was irritating the nerves where the major cutting out of the prostate had occurred. My bad luck. My recovery is now progressing at normal or slightly better so I'm satisfied with the outcome, but totally UNIMPRESSED with the way they handled my care after the surgery. It's like they focus on great surgery and then say to hell with you after that. This may have something to do with the fact that they don't profit at all from patients on Medicare.......so you basically get the bum's rush out of there and they expect you to kiss their rock-star feet and be eternally grateful.

Should I request a CT scan anyway and would it pick up anything in the tissues or seminal vessels? I am being a sponge right now absorbing info .Look forward to your reply Regards, Ron I'm in your situation right now. Well, similar, two of mine were 4/3 and ten clear. They did an MRI with the rectal coil on me and they said it showed cancer in the prostate only......bones were included in that MRI. It is my understanding, though, that the MRI would NOT be able to pick up small amounts of cancer. I'm 67 and I'm having a horribly tough time deciding on this radiation surgery choice. I talk with both radiation and surgery guys soon, so that may help (I sincerely hope).

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon Like you I narrowed it down to Surgery or radiation. I went with robotic surgery (DiVinci) because my urologist said if I chose radiation and the psa started coming back then I would not be able to have the robotic surgery, however if I chose robotic surgery and the psa started climbing I could have radiation. B I'm curious. You mention what your urologist said, but don't say what your radiologist said. I'd like to hear what the radiation people would say in response to what your urologist said. My question would be: why not do radiation and if there were more problems, do more radiation? If there's a downside to that.....is it huge or minimal? These are the kinds of answers we need to make these decisions.
Posts.Title: Just got diagnosed. now what?

Posts.Content: First of all, maybe your family history is a positive thing. If your dad was old enough to have dementia when he was diagnosed he must have been pretty old. Doesn't that give you hope that your cancer may be a non-aggressive type that may not require treatment? In my case, as I was in my late sixties, my doctor said that at my age I probably had prostate cancer because so many men have it at that age (this was early in the process, before I was diagnosed). The only question was......does it need treatment or is it better left alone because it will never impact your life? That's the question for you, I think. Treatment surely will impact your life.....perhaps severely. I suggest a LOT of research before doing anything you can't take back.
Posts.Signature: I will resume more active participation when the bellicose forum culture improves.
Posts.Title: I'm back, and freakout time again

Posts.Content: The doctors seem proud that something other than prostate cancer usually kills the prostate cancer victim before the prostate cancer kills him. I figure that it's often the TREATMENT for prostate cancer that kills--because it exacerbates other existing conditions through stress and side effects. Hormone therapy seems to be the worst, but after coming through the "easy" robotic surgery and finding it anything but easy, I don't doubt that surgery can also be problematic. I know I didn't get a decent night's sleep for six weeks after surgery and it was easily two months before things began to really improve. That stress probably would have killed me if I hadn't been in good physical condition. From what I read, radiation hits some folks fairly hard, too. Obviously, if you need treatment you must get it, because NOT getting it would be a greater risk, but don't let anybody push you into it too soon, especially if you have other health issues (like heart disease) that might be adversely impacted. So, I'm thinking that the least treatment is the best treatment. If you need it, by all means, get it--but don't get it any sooner than necessary. Remember, we tend to hear more from those whose treatment was a cakewalk and less from those who are no longer with us.
Posts.Signature: I will resume more active participation when the bellicose forum culture improves.

Thinking that the experience of another should influence me (or anyone) is, at best, highly speculative.

Posts.Content: You should be just fine. It happens. Be happy that you got your cath out on time. I got an extra week. I had a little bleed when I went for my first long walk at about three months. Posts.Title: Blood in urine. How long?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by WvAl Hello, I'm 5 days post op and experiencing blood from my penis, during bowel movements. I'm taking stool softener and have loose bowels, so I'm not straining much. I am a little concerned about this and wondering if anyone had similar experience. Thank you very much 50yo Gleason 6 May 2012, psa 4.1 Nov 2013, psa 6.1 Radical prostatectomy on 3/12/14 Dr Schaeffer, John Hopkins Yes, I had the same thing......small amounts of blood and urine leaking around the catheter at the tip of the penis during bowel movement. Posts.Title: Bleeding post DaVinci surgery

Posts.Content: The area between the scrotum and anus is sensitive to pressure or any form of stretching or stressing--I suspect this is worse when the surgeon touched or cut either of the nerve bundles that flank the prostate. Thus the doughnut or U-shaped pillow will be a help in most cases. A recliner also helps to shift the pressure farther back and away from that area. I didn't have a pillow on my 45 minute ride home, but I was able to recline the seat. I still felt EVERY bump and irregularity in the roads. It was not pleasant. Once home, I managed without a recliner (since I don't own one). I just slumped on the softest seats I could find and arranged pillows to get comfortable. Had plenty of naps too, as I was not sleeping well at night due to catheter pain.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by d5holmes Last Monday we were told that my 57 year old husband has prostate cancer. It is supposedly in the low to moderate risk category. He hasn't recovered from the biopsy 2 weeks ago yet. He has considerable discomfort. The nurse did not seem impressed. I think that is why I started reading the forum. He is scheduled for robotic prostate removal on April 29. Just getting used to the idea of cancer. In my considerable and recent experience.......nurses NEVER seem impressed by your pain. I think they figure they'll be encouraging your complaining if they seem impressed. They universal response is, "Take a (insert name of pain-killer)." The biopsy hit me pretty hard. It varies. Sometimes they stab in closer to the nerves and that takes longer to heal. I was having pain and a little blood a month later, but it consistently became less as the weeks went by. I think you're doing the right thing. It's no fun, but it's probably the best choice even with all the negatives.

Posts.Content: I guess discussing matters of life and death can bring out the beast. I notice it on this forum too often. The man did not say he was lied to.......he said he felt like he was lied to. He's perfectly entitled to that feeling and no excuse for jumping on him. As far as the actual leakage problem goes, it could simply be a temporary condition from being overtired or fighting off a cold or flu bug. Americans are generally sleep deprived. I can tell you from experience that if you have a few nights of little sleep, perhaps along with a few days of stress......your leakage problem will suddenly get worse and you probably will not know why. First rule: Take care of yourself. Get extra rest. Watch your diet scrupulously. You're recovering from a major life trauma that was a physical and psychological and emotional shock. It rocked your world.......body, soul and spirit. And if that's not it, the other suggestions here have been good. Kegels, etc. I'm fairly slender and athletic looking for being almost 68 and my doc always comments and tells me to keep up the exercise and good eating because that's why I'm doing so well. Take care of yourself.

Posts.Title: Good 6 month followup

Posts.Content: Brachytherapy has had a lot of support here recently, and if you're a candidate for it.....I'd say choose it. It appears to be the least traumatic of the choices. They have a new kind where they remove the seeds after treatment and that appears to be emerging as the new best choice for many. You have to find a facility that is highly regarded and just do it. However, if they insist on hormone therapy in conjunction with the Brachytherapy......I'd just go for surgery instead. The side effects of hormone therapy are such that it's probably better to use that as last rather than first resort. Side effects vary, but I've heard too many people saying too many bad things about hormone therapy--and some simply refusing it even as a last resort. That's just information I've gleaned from nine months of study, but it's been pretty intense study. I ended up choosing surgery, but that was primarily because I had a fair amount of BPH. (I also wanted to get things over quickly and surgery seemed quick.) I really only found out about the problems with hormone therapy later. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: New guy. Just a week ago, I thought male pattern baldness was my main aging concern.

Posts.Content: Was your MRI with rectal coil (and state of the art?). Some MRIs are better than others. Because biopsies do have several risk factors, I insisted on an MRI before biopsy. My MRI showed that cancer in the prostate was highly likely (and even predicted intermediate to aggressive). Subsequent biopsy verified 4/3 prostate cancer. I assume your DRE finger pokings are revealing no abnormalities? How old are you? If your MRI was state of the art and included rectal coil, those who interpret the results should have fairly definitive answers. Doctors tend to downplay the risks of the biopsy, but several kinds of risk do exist.......however, there comes a time when the facts before you will dictate that you must do the biopsy again. You may be there. Get several opinions from experienced specialists and make your decision.

Posts.Title: Good 6 month followup

Posts.Content: “Given the recent spike in infection complications after prostate biopsy, the ideal method to diagnose prostate cancer must be pondered,” Matthew Gettman, professor of urology at the Mayo Graduate School of Medicine in Rochester, Minnesota, wrote in an editorial in the journal European Urology last May. “Despite local anesthetics, the whole procedure is barbaric, and it is surprising that the issue of infection has not come to light years ago.” http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-0...-concerns.html Get a state of the art MRI with rectal coil. It won't harm you in any way and if it shows nothing a biopsy probably won't show anything either. If it shows something.......THEN get the damned barbaric biopsy.

Posts.Title: Finally on Day+1

Posts.Content: Due to scheduling difficulties it was actually about four months before I got my test and that coveted ZERO. Far too many people are testing too early, so I was in no rush and sort of went the other way. I was mentally prepared for bad news, happily going about my daily routine and quite willing to wait a while for that test. What will be, will be, I figure. This is one of those things that you simply can't rush. Do it too early and you are more likely to get a result that scares you for nothing. You can't rush the incontinence and ED, either. "Just Be Patient" is the law you must obey. May as well relax. What will be, will be.

Posts.Content: I've had back pain a lot in the past and it would extend down into the hip. Since I had my prostate removed I've had a ten pound lifting limit, so my back has gotten better to the point where I have zero back pain. Leads me to believe it had nothing to do with cancer and was simply minor and recurring injury from lifting and a bit of sciatica and that all improved when I was forced to be less active. Now if my plumbing would just start functioning more normally, I'd be very happy. Maybe with advice from the proper doctor and rest and some correct therapy your back problems could be fixed.

Posts.Title: very nervous

Posts.Content: Brave, in this situation I'd do an experiment--do a drastic change and see what results. This is to test the theory that your sphincter is suffering from burnout.....like an overuse injury. Don't run at all for three days. Then slowly get back into it by running half your normal distance every other day for a week. Eat smart, get plenty of rest and avoid stress. This, coupled with the cutback on Kegels, will be a big enough change that you should expect noticeable improvement by the end of that ten day period......IF your sphincter is suffering from overuse. I'd think this is the way to go, because it's so hard to believe that your sphincter needs even MORE exercise than your already strenuous program. The secondary theory would be that you have a physical ailment like an infection. That's how I see it. Incontinence is pretty mysterious.

Posts.Title: Return of Leakage

Posts.Content: It's quite possible that the exercise program has been fine for the rest of your body, but a little too much for that sphincter muscle. After all, it's working hard all day and working VERY hard during running due to impact and gravity. Better shoes and a softer running surface could be variables that could help. That muscle probably started to feel like your legs feel after running a marathon......sort of heavy and without much spring. Hard to continue to work effectively after months of continuous marathon running. I've tried to do more on the recumbent exercise bike because it seems there's virtually no extra stress on that sphincter during even the most vigorous exercise bike session and no need for wearing a pad. After almost five months I'm still wearing a light pad when doing something like yard work or going out for a walk, although I probably could get along without it. My doctor says this is well within normal range for an age of late sixties. He's not concerned, so neither am I.

Posts.Title: Return of Leakage

Posts.Content: Yes, less is usually more, although we can't be one hundred percent on that. What's been said thus far should give everyone a good idea of what works well for many. I'd only add that if that little sphincter muscle is SORE..........YOU'RE OVERWORKING IT (caps for emphasis). Overwork will do harm. Age and physical condition are important factors. I am (after a slow seven months) to the point where leakage is little enough that I don't need pads, but sometimes if I'm going to be out and active I'll wear two pair of underwear so none of those few drops can get to the outer clothing. Let me also add that getting plenty of rest is important. If you don't get enough sleep (including, ideally, NAPS) and you are a bit tired......that sphincter will also be a bit tired, your brain will be a bit tired--and you will have more little leaks. Be patient, be smart, listen to the guys who wrote above......and you'll have the best chance of your best possible outcome. As my doc said.......a few drops of urine now and then is no big thing. Of course, he's a urologist and not me. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lancepeace Urology with rectal exams and scopes, etc. is not the most glamorous medical field and many doctors seem kind of crude. Many do DRE's that are kind of aggressive. You could get a FreePSA blood test from your GP. (High is better on this test.) There are other blood tests that are also informative. The chance of complications from a biopsy are low. I got Cipro before and after the biopsy. I would suggest further blood tests at the least. Good luck. Thanks much. I'm hoping for a test that will assess the "dangerousness" of the nodule. That seems to be the Holy Grail that is still the target that many are searching for.......the fact that those three doctors had MRIs as their FIRST test when they themselves had nodules keeps coming back to me.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Otago Well, ideally you would have been better served by having him tell you to wait a few days or a week for the PSA blood draw. If that was easy for you. Either way, your PSA would probably have been 4.0 or more. Do you know your PSA history? The doctor was not wrong to do some extensive "digging around" in the exam. That is exactly the right thing for him to do before making you get biopsy. Right now you may want to get another urologist, but then he will have to re-examine your prostate again and you'll still have to get another PSA.. This time do it prior to the exam, and if possible long enough ahead of time for the new urologist to have the results when you see him for the exam. Then, he'll probably tell you to get a biopsy. Still in the long run, better to deal with someone you feel comfortable with. Whether your PSA is 2.8 or 4.8, with the nodule, they'll tell you to get a biopsy. Or, you can just forget all this and take your chances. Odds are good you'll die from something else before prostate cancer, if you have any, gets to you. That is not a totally unreasonable approach, though some may object to such ideas. Thanks for the info. Yes, doctors tend to want to........doctor. I wish I could get advice from a totally unbiased yet well-informed source. This is an area where almost everybody has at least a little bias, it seems. Yes, the idea that death from something else could save me is a bit counter-intuitive, but it's probably true in this case--the only difficulty is in figuring the odds and making a decision.

Posts.Content: Thanks for the info. As to questions, yes.......I did ask and would still like to hear about alternatives to the biopsy from those who have some knowledge of emerging and state of the art testing......I'd also like to hear why nodules are assumed dangerous without evidence. The info on infections is probably fairly new and still a developing story. http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-0...-concerns.html From the article: Greater recognition of the infectious risks of biopsy has led us to be much more careful about who we select for prostate biopsy, said Stacy Loeb, assistant professor of urology and population health at New York University. All patients should be evaluated for risk factors for resistant bacteria and infection, and should be counseled about the risks and benefits of proceeding to biopsy. That article also mentions that a hospital in Florida has gone to the standard use of the rectal swab before a biopsy to identify dangerous bacteria that might be present, so I don't doubt that others have done the same and more will in the future. I'm quite sure that highly respected medical leaders RARELY call a lot of invasive procedures "barbaric".......probably only the very worst......it appears the prostate biopsy is about the worst. Anyway, when one of the leaders at Mayo calls it "barbaric," I'm going to sit up and take notice. As to your statement on the needles spreading cancer--I can't find any indication that anyone is really keeping track or doing serious research to determine the facts of the matter. Obviously, cancer often spreads to other parts of the body at some point after biopsies, but as to WHY it spreads or whether the biopsy might have been part of the reason it spread........nobody seems to be keeping tabs on it or trying to find correlation between the biopsies and the spread. Maybe they should? Maybe there is reasonable doubt until they do? I don't have a track record of PSA tests although it would be completely normal for them to show as slowly rising to the currently normal 4.8 as I progressed through my 50s and 60s.......and so, that again would be normal and it would only tell us that I'm normal. I welcome all the information I can get and thanks to all who can share.

Posts.Title: Decisions, Decisions......

Posts.Content: Referred to urologist because GP Doc thought he felt something on one side of the prostate. I'm 67 and in good health. Urologist says "You have a nodule." He schedules me for a biopsy. I say ok. (What do I know?) Then he sends me for a blood test to get a PSA count. I say, "When will the results be back?" He says, "I don't know." Disinterested. Doesn't look at me, just keeps tapping on his computer. I give him a confused stare and presently he says, "It doesn't make any difference. We need to do the biopsy." He mumbles something about the results being useful in determining treatment options. Now, maybe my attitude is tainted by the fact that he was a bit rough with the exam. He did everything except put his foot in there and pretend my prostate was a cigarette butt he was grinding out on the pavement.......but I started to distrust and dislike him at the point he said, "I don't know." I mean, technically--I suppose he didn't know EXACTLY when the results would be back, but he could have said, "Usually in a day or two," or something friendly and helpful. I am, after all, pretty vulnerable at this point and friendly answers to questions would naturally be appreciated. I go home and start researching and I find that the PSA should be taken BEFORE the poking and prodding of the prostate--NOT after. I also find that he really glossed over the risks and problems of the biopsy. He quickly said that infections sometimes occurred. Never mentioned that the biopsy can spread existing cancer. Never mentioned that infections have recently been INCREASING and that bacteria that are resistant to penicillin are an INCREASING problem. Never mentioned a rectal swab to check for dangerous bacteria. Never gave me any numbers to assess the risks but did manage to alienate me. Basically, I felt a bit railroaded, treated like a piece of meat and offended by his callous attitude and the total absence of empathy. So.......I learn a lot on my own on the internet and find that the biopsy is dangerous in at least a couple of ways and find especially interesting a story about three doctors who were in my situation and all three chose NOT to have the biopsy and INSTEAD have some sort of MRI as their first test. I find that the head of the MAYO Clinic teaching operation has referred to the current biopsy procedure as "medieval and barbaric." So.......when I find that my PSA turned out to be 4.8, I cancel the biopsy appointment. A 4.8 is NORMAL for a 67-year-old man according to what I've read. I will get together with my GP and talk things over and if he insists I'll start again with a new urologist that will have better social skills and hopefully, better and safer options for tests. The way I see it, we have ZERO evidence that the nodule is dangerous. Actually, I can remember a doctor telling me that one side of my prostate was a little hard about 30 years ago and I think it's been mentioned a couple of other times. Also, from what I've managed to glean from the internet......at age 67 there's a fairly good chance that I could have a slow-moving form of cancer anyway. So why get this prostate all riled up by brutally stabbing it with 12 needles? Should we let a sleeping dog lie or poke it with sharp objects? I really don't know, but maybe some of the folks here can speak to me from their greater experience and add to my now very limited knowledge. Thanks in advance.
Posts.Title: Decisions, Decisions......

Posts.Content: Thanks for the info. As to questions, yes.......I did ask and would still like to hear about alternatives to the biopsy from those who have some knowledge of emerging and state of the art testing......I'd also like to hear why nodules are assumed dangerous without evidence. The info on infections is probably fairly new and still a developing story. http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-0...-concerns.html From the article: Greater recognition of the infectious risks of biopsy has led us to be much more careful about who we select for prostate biopsy, said Stacy Loeb, assistant professor of urology and population health at New York University. All patients should be evaluated for risk factors for resistant bacteria and infection, and should be counseled about the risks and benefits of proceeding to biopsy. That article also mentions that a hospital in Florida has gone to the standard use of the rectal swab before a biopsy to identify dangerous bacteria that might be present, so I don't doubt that others have done the same and more will in the future. I'm quite sure that highly respected medical leaders RARELY call a lot of invasive procedures "barbaric".......probably only the very worst......it appears the prostate biopsy is about the worst. Anyway, when one of the leaders at Mayo calls it "barbaric," I'm going to sit up and take notice. As to your statement on the needles spreading cancer--I can't find any indication that anyone is really keeping track or doing serious research to determine the facts of the matter. Obviously, cancer often spreads to other parts of the body at some point after biopsies, but as to WHY it spreads or whether the biopsy might have been part of the reason it spread........nobody seems to be keeping tabs on it or trying to find correlation between the biopsies and the spread. Maybe they should? Maybe there is reasonable doubt until they do? I don't have a track record of PSA tests although it would be completely normal for them to show as slowly rising to the currently normal 4.8 as I progressed through my 50s and 60s.......and so, that again would be normal and it would only tell us that I'm normal. I welcome all the information I can get and thanks to all who can share.
Posts.Title: Decisions, Decisions......

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Flkjr Welcome Walnut. You will get great insight and advice here. I had Gleason 7 PC with a PSA of 2.9 so that in and of itself is not that indicative of PC. Do you have other symptoms like weak urine flow or ED issues which point to an enlarged prostate? I had three biopsies ever 6 years to check for PC and never had any issues of infection or pain. I had what I considered a very conscientious and experienced urologist who I trusted enough to do my surgery and believe he has got me cancer free. They do exist and I would suggest you find yourself one. Good luck and stay positive, Fran Thanks, I'm sexually functional (a little slowed down at 67, but working without drugs so far) and I can sleep through until five or six a.m. most nights, so I'd regard my urinary function about par for age maybe better than some. Yes, I suppose there will be a second try at a urologist sooner rather than later. I'm just hoping to hear of better tests coming along.
Posts.Title: Decisions, Decisions......

Posts.Content: Referred to urologist because GP Doc thought he felt something on one side of the prostate. I'm 67 and in good health. Urologist says "You have a nodule." He schedules me for a biopsy. I say ok. (What do I know?) Then he sends me for a blood test to get a PSA count. I say, "When will the results be back?" He says, "I don't know." Disinterested. Doesn't look at me, just keeps tapping on his computer. I give him a confused stare and presently he says, "It doesn't make any difference. We need to do the biopsy." He mumbles something about the results being useful in determining treatment options. Now, maybe my attitude is tainted by the fact that he was a bit rough with the exam. He did everything except put his foot in there and pretend my prostate was a cigarette butt he was grinding out on the pavement.......but I started to distrust and dislike him at the point he said, "I don't know." I mean, technically--I suppose he didn't know EXACTLY when the results would be back, but he could have said, "Usually in a day or two," or something friendly and helpful. I am, after all, pretty vulnerable at this point and friendly answers to questions would naturally be appreciated. I go home and start researching and I find that the PSA should be taken BEFORE the poking and prodding of the prostate--NOT after. I also find that he really glossed over the risks and problems of the biopsy. He quickly said that infections sometimes occurred. Never mentioned that the biopsy can spread existing cancer. Never mentioned that infections have recently been INCREASING and that bacteria that are resistant to penicillin are an INCREASING problem. Never mentioned a rectal swab to check for dangerous bacteria. Never gave me any numbers to assess the risks but did manage to alienate me. Basically, I felt a bit railroaded, treated like a piece of meat and offended by his callous attitude and the total absence of empathy. So.......I learn a lot on my own on the internet and find that the biopsy is dangerous in at least a couple of ways and find especially interesting a story about three doctors who were in my situation and all three chose NOT to have the biopsy and INSTEAD have some sort of MRI as their first test. I find that the head of the MAYO Clinic teaching operation has referred to the current biopsy procedure as "medieval and barbaric." So.......when I find that my PSA turned out to be 4.8, I cancel the biopsy appointment. A 4.8 is NORMAL for a 67-year-old man according to what I've read. I will get together with my GP and talk things over and if he insists I'll start again with a new urologist that will have better social skills and hopefully, better and safer options for tests. The way I see it, we have ZERO evidence that the nodule is dangerous. Actually, I can remember a doctor telling me that one side of my prostate was a little hard about 30 years ago and I think it's been mentioned a couple of other times. Also, from what I've managed to glean from the internet......at age 67 there's a fairly good chance that I could have a slow-moving form of cancer anyway. So why get this prostate all riled up by brutally stabbing it with 12 needles? Should we let a sleeping dog lie or poke it with sharp objects? I really don't know, but maybe some of the folks here can speak to me from their greater experience and add to my now very limited knowledge. Thanks in advance.
Posts.Title: Decisions, Decisions......

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lancepeace Urology with rectal exams and scopes, etc. is not the most glamorous medical field and many doctors seem kind of crude. Many do DRE's that are kind of aggressive. You could get a FreePSA blood test from your GP. (High is better on this test.) There are other blood tests that are also informative. The chance of complications from a biopsy are low. I got Cipro before and after the biopsy. I would suggest further blood tests at the least. Good luck. Thanks much. I'm hoping for a test that will assess the "dangerousness" of the nodule. That seems to be the Holy Grail that is still the target that many are searching for.......the fact that those three doctors had MRIs as their FIRST test when they themselves had nodules keeps coming back to me.

Posts.Title: Decisions, Decisions......

Posts.Content: Not every urologist will rush you into a biopsy. Yes, it's a moneymaker for them. No, that doesn't necessarily mean they will be greedy. I suspect if you take Highlander's advice very seriously (no bike, no sex, etc.) you may do better on the blood test and that will end the problem. If you ever DO get to the point of deciding on a biopsy......insist on a state of the art MRI with rectal coil BEFORE the biopsy. No point in going directly to the invasive procedure.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Otago Well, ideally you would have been better served by having him tell you to wait a few days or a week for the PSA blood draw. If that was easy for you. Either way, your PSA would probably have been 4.0 or more. Do you know your PSA history? The doctor was not wrong to do some extensive "digging around" in the exam. That is exactly the right thing for him to do before making you get biopsy. Right now you may want to get another urologist, but then he will have to re-examine your prostate again and you'll still have to get another PSA.. This time do it prior to the exam, and if possible long enough ahead of time for the new urologist to have the results when you see him for the exam. Then, he'll probably tell you to get a biopsy. Still in the long run, better to deal with someone you feel comfortable with. Whether your PSA is 2.8 or 4.8, with the nodule, they'll tell you to get a biopsy. Or, you can just forget all this and take your chances. Odds are good you'll die from something else before prostate cancer, if you have any, gets to you. That is not a totally unreasonable approach, though some may object to such ideas. Thanks for the info. Yes, doctors tend to want to........doctor. I wish I could get advice from a totally unbiased yet well-informed source. This is an area where almost everybody has at least a little bias, it seems. Yes, the idea that death from something else could save me is a bit counter-intuitive, but it's probably true in this case--the only difficulty is in figuring the odds and making a decision.

That seems to be the Holy Grail that is still the target that many are searching for.......the fact that those three doctors had MRIs as their FIRST test when they themselves had nodules keeps coming back to me.
Posts.Title: Decisions, Decisions......

Posts.Content: Referred to urologist because GP Doc thought he felt something on one side of the prostate. I'm 67 and in good health. Urologist says "You have a nodule." He schedules me for a biopsy. I say ok. (What do I know?) Then he sends me for a blood test to get a PSA count. I say, "When will the results be back?" He says, "I don't know." Disinterested. Doesn't look at me, just keeps tapping on his computer. I give him a confused stare and presently he says, "It doesn't make any difference. We need to do the biopsy." He mumbles something about the results being useful in determining treatment options. Now, maybe my attitude is tainted by the fact that he was a bit rough with the exam. He did everything except put his foot in there and pretend my prostate was a cigarette butt he was grinding out on the pavement.......but I started to distrust and dislike him at the point he said, "I don't know." I mean, technically--I suppose he didn't know EXACTLY when the results would be back, but he could have said, "Usually in a day or two," or something friendly and helpful. I am, after all, pretty vulnerable at this point and friendly answers to questions would naturally be appreciated. I go home and start researching and I find that the PSA should be taken BEFORE the poking and prodding of the prostate--NOT after. I also find that he really glossed over the risks and problems of the biopsy. He quickly said that infections sometimes occurred. Never mentioned that the biopsy can spread existing cancer. Never mentioned that infections have recently been INCREASING and that bacteria that are resistant to penicillin are an INCREASING problem. Never mentioned a rectal swab to check for dangerous bacteria. Never gave me any numbers to assess the risks but did manage to alienate me. Basically, I felt a bit railroaded, treated like a piece of meat and offended by his callous attitude and the total absence of empathy. So.......I learn a lot on my own on the internet and find that the biopsy is dangerous in at least a couple of ways and find especially interesting a story about three doctors who were in my situation and all three chose NOT to have the biopsy and INSTEAD have some sort of MRI as their first test. I find that the head of the MAYO Clinic teaching operation has referred to the current biopsy procedure as "medieval and barbaric." So.......when I find that my PSA turned out to be 4.8, I cancel the biopsy appointment. A 4.8 is NORMAL for a 67-year-old man according to what I've read. I will get together with my GP and talk things over and if he insists I'll start again with a new urologist that will have better social skills and hopefully, better and safer options for tests. The way I see it, we have ZERO evidence that the nodule is dangerous. Actually, I can remember a doctor telling me that one side of my prostate was a little hard about 30 years ago and I think it's been mentioned a couple of other times. Also, from what I've managed to glean from the internet......at age 67 there's a fairly good chance that I could have a slow-moving form of cancer anyway. So why get this prostate all riled up by brutally stabbing it with 12 needles? Should we let a sleeping dog lie or poke it with sharp objects? I really don't know, but maybe some of the folks here can speak to me from their greater experience and add to my now very limited knowledge. Thanks in advance.
Posts.Title: Decisions, Decisions......

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Otago Well, ideally you would have been better served by having him tell you to wait a few days or a week for the PSA blood draw. If that was easy for you. Either way, your PSA would probably have been 4.0 or more. Do you know your PSA history? The doctor was not wrong to do some extensive "digging around" in the exam. That is exactly the right thing for him to do before making you get biopsy. Right now you may want to get another urologist, but then he will have to re-examine your prostate again and you'll still have to get another PSA.. This time do it prior to the exam, and if possible long enough ahead of time for the new urologist to have the results when you see him for the exam. Then, he'll probably tell you to get a biopsy. Still in the long run, better to deal with someone you feel comfortable with. Whether your PSA is 2.8 or 4.8, with the nodule, they'll tell you to get a biopsy. Or, you can just forget all this and take your chances. Odds are good you'll die from something else before prostate cancer, if you have any, gets to you. That is not a totally unreasonable approach, though some may object to such ideas. Thanks for the info. Yes, doctors tend to want to........doctor. I wish I could get advice from a totally unbiased yet well-informed source. This is an area where almost everybody has at least a little bias, it seems. Yes, the idea that death from something else could save me is a bit counter-intuitive, but it's probably true in this case--the only difficulty is in figuring the odds and making a decision.

Posts.Title: Gleason 4+4, Starting Lupron

Posts.Content: It's a mystery. How does the stress of that damage to your home figure into the urinary retention??????? Apparently stress hit you very hard. How does that figure into the high PSA??? Here's a fact. One PSA doesn't prove anything. I would say proceed with stress counseling, second and third opinions and get a state of the art MRI at a highly rated facility. You can always get a biopsy if the MRI shows something suspicious.

Posts.Title: High PSA Reading of 285

Posts.Content: Since I'm in the middle of this same situation, I'll weigh in. Exercise must be smart and moderate, starting with Kegels. Don't do too many. Your walking may have been excessive. Remember, when you walk you tend to be working that lone little remaining sphincter almost constantly so as not to leak and that tends to overwork it and it can suffer from burnout.......you must nurture that tiny muscle. So easing off for a bit could be good strategy as Mikem suggested. As you get back into it.....walking every day and alternating two miles and four mile days might be better. My early post surgery routine was to walk around the house (including two flights of stairs) for 15 to 20 minutes daily and five minute walks at least every two hours. My strategy has always been that I end the walking session if I start to get significant leakage. To me that indicates that the sphincter is overtired and further walking may be detrimental. I have a semi-recumbent exercise bike--and at about two months I used it for about ten minutes one day and then 20 minutes the next day and had a few drops of blood in the pad (this was noted later in the day after a walk of about a mile). Later I had a little blood at the start of urine flow on one urination. Checked with doc and he just said to call him if the bleeding continued and ease off on exercise. No more bleeding. So......I kept up my usual routine and added some walks up to three miles outside. I did want to get back on the bike, though, so after waiting about a month I put a box under the front of the bike to make it even more recumbent (this shifts pressure to the tailbone and back rather than the prostate area) and tried it again. No blood and I have been gradually increasing my time on the bike. I think that, after enough healing has occurred so you can safely use the bike, the recumbent bike is actually better than walking because you don't tend to leak as you do with walking, therefore the sphincter does not get stressed. I do six ten-second Kegals (with thirty seconds in between them) before bed at night as Mayo recommended and have added another set of six during the day now with their permission. At four months I am still using a pad during the day at times when I'm active and no pad when fairly inactive. Leakage is minor, but still happens. I'm 67 years old and in pretty good health otherwise. Age is indeed a factor in how soon you can expect to be dry.......or shall we say, mostly dry. I don't think most doctors expect perfection in this issue. It was revealing to me when my doctor said, "A few drops of urine once in a while is no big deal." Reading between the lines, I think the message is that few of us can expect to ever be as dry as we were before surgery......at least that's my impression. My main advice I can give from my experience is: be patient, don't worry, be moderate in exercise and all things, drink enough water but not too much and enjoy your life. Especially go easy on alcohol and caffeine. I drink decaf (which still has a bit of caffeine) and I always have a glass of wine in the evening. Remember to avoid stress and worry and nurture and cherish that one small remaining sphincter and things should turn out well.

Posts.Title: Exercise Bicycle

Posts.Content: It's neither a walk in the park nor a piece of cake. It's tough mentally and physically. I had the catheter for 15 memorable and unhappy days. Hope you do better with it. But, most of us get through it quite well if we have it done at an excellent facility by an experienced surgeon. I'm now almost 12 months out and while I'd never want to do those first three months again, it was better than keeping the cancer. My PSA is normal and I'd call the incontinence/ED part of it at above 95% of normal. I don't have to use pads anymore, but nice thick cotton underwear is recommended just in case. If you're younger than me, (I'm 69) you'll probably recover faster and with less annoyance. My doc says a few drops of urine here and there is just no big deal. He's right, of course, but it would be nice to have zero drops of urine. You tend to wonder if you'll ever get to that level. I hope I do. So, it's been unpleasant at times, but you'll get through it like most of us do. Read all the stickies here carefully and take note of all the good advice. You should do just fine, but don't be fooled by the "walk in the park, piece of cake" crap. Some may be that lucky, but that does NOT mean that everybody is that lucky. I'd call it a walk in the dark and a piece of cheap steak. It's not enjoyable, but if you keep your wits about you......you can get through it and beat cancer.
